G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County Superior Court under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 2, because the cause of action arose in Suffolk County, specifically at or near 1234 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, MA 02215.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because Defendant resides in Massachusetts and/or regularly operates a motor vehicle within the Commonwealth, and the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Boston, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 89.proposition: Commonwealth Avenue is a public roadway in the City of Boston, subject to the traffic laws and regulations of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including, but not limited to, G.L. c. 89, G.L. c. 90, and G.L. c. 85.

G.L. c. 90.proposition: Commonwealth Avenue is a public roadway in the City of Boston, subject to the traffic laws and regulations of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including, but not limited to, G.L. c. 89, G.L. c. 90, and G.L. c. 85.

G.L. c. 85.proposition: Commonwealth Avenue is a public roadway in the City of Boston, subject to the traffic laws and regulations of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including, but not limited to, G.L. c. 89, G.L. c. 90, and G.L. c. 85.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a driver or occupant of a motor vehicle owes a duty to exercise reasonable care toward all foreseeable users of the highway, including bicyclists using a marked bike lane.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion in Glidden v. Maglio concerns premises liability and negligence claims arising from a scaffolding collapse at a residential construction site. It does not involve motor vehicles, drivers or occupants, highways, or bicyclists, nor does it articulate any duty owed by drivers to foreseeable users of the highway. The case therefore does not provide authority for the proposition about a motorist’s duty of care to bicyclists in a marked bike lane.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.relevant_excerpt: "With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. ... The plaintiffs point to nothing of substance to suggest that the judge erred in either respect. To the contrary, the record reflects that the plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed..."

Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.raw_text: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 902–03 (1987)
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a driver or occupant of a motor vehicle owes a duty to exercise reasonable care toward all foreseeable users of the highway, including bicyclists using a marked bike lane.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a premises-liability/negligent-security type claim against a restaurant for injuries caused when an out-of-control vehicle crashed into the building. It analyzes foreseeability and duty owed by a landowner to its patrons, not the duty of a motor vehicle driver or occupant to bicyclists or other highway users. Nothing in the excerpt addresses duties of drivers or occupants toward bicyclists or marked bike lanes, so it does not support the stated proposition about Massachusetts common law obligations of motorists to foreseeable highway users.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner or proprietor is not an insurer of the safety of his patrons. ‘The test is “foreseeable harm.” … The underlying duty in every case, however, is to exercise the care which the circumstances reasonably require.’ Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341 Mass. 640, 642 (1961). … The undisputed facts of this case make the injuries suffered by the plaintiffs the result of an incident which was not reasonably foreseeable by the defendant and thus not an occurrence from which it had a duty to protect its patrons.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: Negligence in Massachusetts is established where the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care, breached that duty, and such breach was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries and damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the elements a plaintiff must prove to prevail on a negligence claim in Massachusetts: duty of reasonable care, breach, damage, and a causal relation between breach and damage. This is substantively the same as the proposition’s formulation that negligence is established where the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care, breached that duty, and such breach was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries and damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: "3. Negligence claim, a. Duty of care, generally. To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage."

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 56 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: Negligence in Massachusetts is established where the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care, breached that duty, and such breach was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries and damages.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a dissent focused almost entirely on proximate cause and evidentiary sufficiency, not on articulating the general elements of negligence. While it briefly quotes Cimino for a foreseeability-based causation standard, it does not set out the full Massachusetts negligence elements (duty, breach, proximate cause, and damages) as a doctrinal formula. The main opinion in Mullins does discuss duty and negligence, but that text is not provided here, so this excerpt alone does not clearly support the broad black-letter proposition cited.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Specifically, G.L. c. 90, § 14 provides in relevant part that: “No person shall open a door on a motor vehicle unless it is reasonably safe to do so without interfering with the movement of other traffic, including bicyclists, or leave a door open on the side of a vehicle available to moving traffic for a period of time longer than necessary to load or unload passengers.”

G.L. c. 89, \u00a7\u00a7 1\u20134B.proposition: Under G.L. c. 89, §§ 1–4B, and G.L. c. 90, §§ 14 and 17, motorists must operate and act with due care so as not to endanger the lives or safety of any person lawfully using the roadway, including those in designated bicycle lanes.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7\u00a7 14 and 17.proposition: Under G.L. c. 89, §§ 1–4B, and G.L. c. 90, §§ 14 and 17, motorists must operate and act with due care so as not to endanger the lives or safety of any person lawfully using the roadway, including those in designated bicycle lanes.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: The violation of a safety statute designed to protect the class of persons of which Plaintiff is a member (bicyclists), such as G.L. c. 90, § 14, may be considered evidence of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the evidentiary effect of violating a safety-related statute (G.L. c. 138, § 69) and states that such a violation is not negligence per se but is only ‘some evidence’ of negligence for consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Although the statute in Bennett concerns alcohol service rather than bicyclist safety, the legal principle about statutory violations as evidence of negligence is general and clearly supports the proposition that violation of a safety statute designed to protect a class of persons (such as bicyclists) may be considered evidence of negligence, not conclusive proof. Thus the case is good authority for the evidentiary use of statutory violations in negligence cases.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: "It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only 'some evidence' of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968)."

LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.raw_text: LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28–29 (1979)
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.proposition: The violation of a safety statute designed to protect the class of persons of which Plaintiff is a member (bicyclists), such as G.L. c. 90, § 14, may be considered evidence of negligence.
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.case_name: LaClair v. Silberline Manufacturing Co., Inc.
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the Massachusetts rule that violation of a safety statute or similar enactment is evidence of negligence, though not conclusive of liability. The court applies that principle to the employer’s violation of the compulsory workers’ compensation law as a safety/humanitarian statute. While the case involves employees rather than bicyclists or G.L. c. 90, § 14 specifically, it clearly supports the broader evidentiary principle that violation of a safety statute designed to protect a class of persons is evidence of negligence.
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “As has been frequently stated, a violation of a safety statute or like enactment, while not conclusive on the ultimate issue of civil liability, is evidence of a violator’s negligence as to all consequences that the statute was intended to prevent. Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836, 841 (1976). Underlying this rule is the general belief that the duties imposed by legislatively-prescribed conduct are normally reasonable ones to bear.”

Commonwealth v. Campbell, 394 Mass. 77,.proposition: Massachusetts case law recognizes that motorists and others using public ways must anticipate the presence of cyclists and act with reasonable care toward them.
Commonwealth v. Campbell, 394 Mass. 77,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns vehicular homicide while operating under the influence and focuses on sufficiency of the evidence, statutory construction, jury instructions, and issues of contributory negligence. It does not discuss duties of motorists toward cyclists or the need to anticipate the presence of cyclists on public ways. Nothing in the reasoning or holding addresses cyclists or articulates a specific standard of care owed to them, so the case does not support the stated proposition.
Commonwealth v. Campbell, 394 Mass. 77,.relevant_excerpt: The judge told the jurors in substance that they had to find that the defendant operated a motor vehicle on a public way while he was under the influence of intoxicating liquor and “that the operation of the vehicle was . . . either reckless ... or, in the alternative, that the vehicle was operated in a negligent manner so that the lives and safety of the public might be endangered.” He further instructed that “such operation [must] cause[ ] the death of another person.”

Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 756\u20135.proposition: Massachusetts case law recognizes that motorists and others using public ways must anticipate the presence of cyclists and act with reasonable care toward them.
Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 756\u20135.support_reasoning: The opinion is about municipal liability for police failure to remove an intoxicated motorist and the duties arising from statutes regarding drunk driving. It does not address the obligations of motorists or other road users toward cyclists, nor does it discuss a duty to anticipate cyclists on public ways. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition regarding motorists’ duties to cyclists.
Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 756\u20135.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that there is a special relationship between a police officer who negligently fails to remove an intoxicated motorist from the highway, and a member of the public who suffers injury as a result of that failure. The statutes which establish police responsibilities in such circumstances evidence a legislative intent to protect both intoxicated persons and other users of the highway. As to the most crucial factor — foreseeability — the calamitous consequences to the victims of accidents caused by drunken driving are all too predictable.

Mass. Gen. Laws c. 90, \u00a7 13B.proposition: A driver’s or occupant’s distraction caused by the use of a cell phone or other device does not excuse the failure to maintain a proper lookout and comply with duties under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B.proposition: Under G.L. c. 85, § 11B, bicycles are permitted on most public ways, and bicyclists are generally afforded the rights and subject to the duties of drivers of vehicles, further establishing that Plaintiff was lawfully present and entitled to protection as a roadway user.

Hudson v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.raw_text: Hudson v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 481 Mass. 282, 286–87 (2019)
Hudson v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.proposition: The presence of a marked bicycle lane on Commonwealth Avenue emphasizes that bicyclists are a foreseeable and expected part of traffic, and that motorists and occupants must account for cyclists’ presence when stopping, standing, and opening doors.
Hudson v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.support_reasoning: The provided text is from a homicide case concerning sufficiency of evidence, cell-site location information, video evidence, and trial procedure. It does not address roadway design, bicycle lanes, or motorists’ duties toward cyclists, nor does it mention Commonwealth Avenue or dooring-type liability. Therefore it cannot serve as authority for the traffic/bicycle-lane proposition stated.

Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828, 832 (199.proposition: The presence of a marked bicycle lane on Commonwealth Avenue emphasizes that bicyclists are a foreseeable and expected part of traffic, and that motorists and occupants must account for cyclists’ presence when stopping, standing, and opening doors.
Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828, 832 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion deals entirely with personal liability of hospital employees for workplace safety on a roof, not with roadway use, bicycles, bike lanes, or duties of motorists and vehicle occupants when opening doors. Nothing in the reasoning or holding concerns traffic, foreseeability of cyclists, or the legal significance of a marked bicycle lane on Commonwealth Avenue. The proposition about bicycle lanes and motorists’ duties is unrelated to the subject matter of Lyon v. Morphew, so the case does not support it.
Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828, 832 (199.relevant_excerpt:
“We have never recognized a common law duty of building owners to place or maintain fall protection safety devices on roofs.

Furthermore, State and Federal safety regulations do not require property owners to install and maintain fall protection devices on low pitched roofs… Absent a statutory or common law duty, the director and assistant director may not be held individually liable for failing to replace the safety railing prior to the accident.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts comparative negligence law, G.L. c. 231, § 85, a plaintiff’s recovery is not barred unless the plaintiff’s negligence exceeds that of the defendant.

O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.raw_text: O’Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 401 Mass. 586, 589 (1988)
O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.proposition: Disputed issues of witness credibility are for the trier of fact.
O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on jury instructions regarding exposure and causation in an asbestos case and on whether any instructional errors were prejudicial. It does not discuss or articulate any rule about how disputed issues of witness credibility are to be treated, nor does it reference credibility determinations as being reserved to the trier of fact. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6C.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C, Plaintiff also seeks prejudgment and post‑judgment interest on any verdict, award, or judgment in this action, at the statutory rate.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff respectfully demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
